member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.PropertySystem.IPropertyChangeArray
member.summary: Exposes methods for several multiple change operations that may be passed to .
member.remarks: Either call CoCreateInstance with a class identifier (CLSID) of CLSID_PropertyChangeArray or call PSCreatePropertyChangeArray to obtain a standard implementation of this interface. This is a container interface that allows multiple changes to be passed to a single file operation to prevent accessing a file multiple times.

member.param: A pointer to the number of change operations.
member.returns: Always returns .

member.summary: Gets the change operation at a specified array index.
member.param: The index of the change to retrieve.
A reference to the desired IID.
The address of a pointer to the interface specified by riid, usually .
member.returns: If this method succeeds, it returns . Otherwise, it returns an error code.

member.summary: Replaces the first occurrence of a change that affects the same property key as the provided change. If the property key is not already in the array, this method appends the change to the end of the array.

member.summary: The date portion of date/time hidden.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.PropertySystem.PropertyDescriptionFormatOptions.UseEditInvitation
member.summary: The text displayed in a text box as a cue for the user, such as 'Enter your name'.
member.remarks: The invitation text is returned if formatting failed or the value was empty. Invitation text is text displayed in a text box as a cue for the user, Formatting can fail if the data entered is not of an expected type, such as putting alpha characters in a phone number field.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.PropertySystem.PropertyDescriptionFormatOptions.ReadOnly
member.summary: This flag requires UseEditInvitation to also be specified. When the formatting flags are ReadOnly | UseEditInvitation and the algorithm would have shown invitation text, a string is returned that indicates the value is "Unknown" instead of the invitation text.

member.summary: The detection of the reading order is not automatic. Useful when converting to ANSI to omit the Unicode reading order characters.

member.summary: The user can group by this property.

member.summary: The user can stack by this property.

member.summary: This property contains a hierarchy.

member.summary: Include this property in any full text query that is performed.
member.remarks: This value is set by the includeInFullTextQuery attribute of the typeInfo element in the property's .propdesc file.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.PropertySystem.PropertyTypeOptions.IsViewable
member.summary: This property is meant to be viewed by the user.
member.remarks: This influences whether the property shows up in the "Choose Columns" dialog, for example. This value is set by the isViewable attribute of the typeInfo element in the property's .propdesc file.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.PropertySystem.PropertyTypeOptions.IsQueryable
member.summary: This property is included in the list of properties that can be queried.
member.remarks: A queryable property must also be viewable. This influences whether the property shows up in the query builder UI. This value is set by the isQueryable attribute of the typeInfo element in the property's .propdesc file.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.PropertySystem.PropertyTypeOptions.CanBePurged
member.summary: Used with an innate property (that is, a value calculated from other property values) to indicate that it can be deleted.
member.remarks: Windows Vista with Service Pack 1 (SP1) and later. This value is used by the Remove Properties user interface (UI) to determine whether to display a check box next to an property that allows that property to be selected for removal. Note that a property that is not innate can always be purged regardless of the presence or absence of this flag.

summary.para: Description: Hash to determine acquisition session.
Type: -- (For variants: ) Legacy code may treat this as .
Type: Multivalue -- | (For variants: | ) Legacy code may treat this as .
Description: The amount of total space in bytes.
Description: Legacy code treats this as .
Type: -- (For variants: ) Legacy code may treat this as .

Description: The list of type of items, this item contains. For example, this item contains urls, attachments etc. This is represented as a vector array of GUIDs where each GUID represents certain type.
Description: The time of the last access to the item. The Indexing Service friendly name is 'access'.

Description: The time the file entered the system via acquisition. This is not the same as System.DateImported. Examples are when pictures are acquired from a camera, or when music is purchased online.
Description: The date and time the item was created. The Indexing Service friendly name is 'create'.
Description: The time the file is imported into a separate database. This is not the same as System.DateAcquired. (Eg, 2003:05:22 13:55:04)
Description: The date and time of the last write to the item. The Indexing Service friendly name is 'write'.
Description: The contents of a SHDESCRIPTIONID structure as a buffer of bytes.
Description: This is the WIN32_FIND_DATA dwFileAttributes for the file-based item.
Description: This is a user-friendly description of the file.

Description: This is the file extension of the file based item, including the leading period.
If System.FileName is , then this property should be too. Otherwise, it should be derived appropriately by the data source from System.FileName. If System.FileName does not have a file extension, this value should be .
To obtain the type of any item (including an item that is not a file), use System.ItemType.
Example values:
If the path is... The property value is... ----------------- ------------------------ "c:\foo\bar\hello.txt"".txt" "\\server\share\mydir\goodnews.doc" ".doc" "\\server\share\numbers.xls" ".xls" "\\server\share\folder" "c:\foo\MyFolder" [desktop]

Description: This is the unique file ID, also known as the File Reference Number. For a given file, this is the same value as is found in the structure variable FILE_ID_BOTH_DIR_INFO.FileId, via GetFileInformationByHandleEx().

Description: This is the file name (including extension) of the file.
It is possible that the item might not exist on a filesystem (ie, it may not be opened using CreateFile). Nonetheless, if the item is represented as a file from the logical sense (and its name follows standard Win32 file-naming syntax), then the data source should emit this property.
If an item is not a file, then the value for this property is . See System.ItemNameDisplay.
This has the same value as System.ParsingName for items that are provided by the Shell's file folder.
Example values:
If the path is... The property value is... ----------------- ------------------------ "c:\foo\bar\hello.txt""hello.txt" "\\server\share\mydir\goodnews.doc" "goodnews.doc" "\\server\share\numbers.xls" "numbers.xls" "c:\foo\MyFolder" "MyFolder" (email message) (song on portable device) "song.wma"
Description: This is the owner of the file, according to the file system.
Description: WIN32_FIND_DATAW in buffer of bytes.
Description: This is the user-friendly form of System.FlagColor. Not intended to be parsed programmatically.
Description: Status of Flag. Values: (0=none 1=white 2=Red). cdoPR_FLAG_STATUS
Description: This is the user-friendly form of System.FlagStatus. Not intended to be parsed programmatically.
Description: The amount of free space in bytes.

Description: This PKEY is used to specify search terms that should be applied as broadly as possible, across all valid properties for the data source(s) being searched. It should not be emitted from a data source.
Description: This is the user-friendly form of System.Importance. Not intended to be parsed programmatically.
Description: The text (with formatted property values) to show in the infotip.
Description: Identifies if this item is an attachment.
Description: Identifies the default save location for a library for non-owners of the library
Description: Identifies the default save location for a library for the owner of the library
Description: Identifies if the message was not completely received for some error condition.
Description: A bool value to know if a location is supported (locally indexable, or remotely indexed).
Description: A bool value to know if a shell folder is pinned to the navigation pane
Description: Has the item been read?
Description: Identifies if a location or a library is search only
Description: Provided by certain shell folders. Return TRUE if the folder is a valid Send To target.
Description: Is this item .Shared? This only checks for ACLs that are not inherited.

Description: This is the generic list of authors associated with an item.
For example, the artist name for a track is the item author.

Description: This is the main date for an item. The date of interest.
For example, for photos this maps to System.Photo.DateTaken.

Description: This is the user-friendly display name of the parent folder of an item.
If System.ItemFolderPathDisplay is , then this property should be too. Otherwise, it should be derived appropriately by the data source from System.ItemFolderPathDisplay.
If the folder is a file folder, the value will be localized if a localized name is available.
Example values:
If the path is... The property value is... ----------------- ------------------------ "c:\foo\bar\hello.txt""bar" "\\server\share\mydir\goodnews.doc" "mydir" "\\server\share\numbers.xls" "share" "c:\foo\MyFolder" "foo" "/Mailbox Account/Inbox/'Re: Hello!'" "Inbox"

Description: This is the user-friendly display path of the parent folder of an item.
If System.ItemPathDisplay is , then this property should be too. Otherwise, it should be derived appropriately by the data source from System.ItemPathDisplay.
Example values:
If the path is... The property value is... ----------------- ------------------------ "c:\foo\bar\hello.txt""c:\foo\bar" "\\server\share\mydir\goodnews.doc" "\\server\share\mydir" "\\server\share\numbers.xls" "\\server\share" "c:\foo\MyFolder" "c:\foo" "/Mailbox Account/Inbox/'Re: Hello!'" "/Mailbox Account/Inbox"

Description: This is the user-friendly display path of the parent folder of an item. The format of the should be tailored such that the folder name comes first, to optimize for a narrow viewing column.
If the folder is a file folder, the value includes localized names if they are present.
If System.ItemFolderPathDisplay is , then this property should be too. Otherwise, it should be derived appropriately by the data source from System.ItemFolderPathDisplay.
Example values:
If the path is... The property value is... ----------------- ------------------------ "c:\foo\bar\hello.txt""bar (c:\foo)" "\\server\share\mydir\goodnews.doc" "mydir (\\server\share)" "\\server\share\numbers.xls" "share (\\server)" "c:\foo\MyFolder" "foo (c:\)" "/Mailbox Account/Inbox/'Re: Hello!'" "Inbox (/Mailbox Account)"

Description: This is the base-name of the System.ItemNameDisplay.
If the item is a file this property includes the extension in all cases, and will be localized if a localized name is available.
If the item is a message, then the value of this property does not include the forwarding or reply prefixes (see System.ItemNamePrefix).

Description: This is the display name in "most complete" form. This is the best effort unique representation of the name of an item that makes sense for end users to read. It is the concatentation of System.ItemNamePrefix and System.ItemName.
If the item is a file this property includes the extension in all cases, and will be localized if a localized name is available.
There are acceptable cases when System.FileName is not , yet the value of this property is completely different. Email messages are a key example. If the item is an email message, the item name is likely the subject. In that case, the value must be the concatenation of the System.ItemNamePrefix and System.ItemName. Since the value of System.ItemNamePrefix excludes any trailing whitespace, the concatenation must include a whitespace when generating System.ItemNameDisplay.
Note that this property is not guaranteed to be unique, but the idea is to promote the most likely candidate that can be unique and also makes sense for end users. For example, for documents, you might think about using System.Title as the System.ItemNameDisplay, but in practice the title of the documents may not be useful or unique enough to be of value as the sole System.ItemNameDisplay. Instead, providing the value of System.FileName as the value of System.ItemNameDisplay is a better candidate. In Windows Mail, the emails are stored in the file system as .eml files and the System.FileName for those files are not human-friendly as they contain GUIDs. In this example, promoting System.Subject as System.ItemNameDisplay makes more sense.
Compatibility notes:
Shell folder implementations on Vista: use PKEY_ItemNameDisplay for the name column when you want Explorer to call ISF::GetDisplayNameOf(SHGDN_NORMAL) to get the value of the name. Use another PKEY (like PKEY_ItemName) when you want Explorer to call either the folder's property store or ISF2::GetDetailsEx in order to get the value of the name.
Shell folder implementations on XP: the first column needs to be the name column, and Explorer will call ISF::GetDisplayNameOf to get the value of the name. The PKEY/SCID does not matter.
Example values:
File: "hello.txt" Message: "Re: Let's talk about Tom's argyle socks!" Device folder: "song.wma" Folder:"Documents"

Description: This is the prefix of an item, used for email messages. where the subject begins with "Re:" which is the prefix.
If the item is a file, then the value of this property is .
If the item is a message, then the value of this property is the forwarding or reply prefixes (including delimiting colon, but no whitespace), or if there is no prefix.
Example values:
System.ItemNamePrefixSystem.ItemName System.ItemNameDisplay ---------------------------------------- ---------------------- "Great day" "Great day" "Re:""Great day" "Re: Great day" "Fwd: " "Monthly budget" "Fwd: Monthly budget" "accounts.xls" "accounts.xls"

Description: This is the generic list of people associated with an item and who contributed to the item.
For example, this is the combination of people in the To list, Cc list and sender of an email message.

Description: This is the user-friendly display path to the item.
If the item is a file or folder this property includes the extension in all cases, and will be localized if a localized name is available.
For other items,this is the user-friendly equivalent, assuming the item exists in hierarchical storage.
Unlike System.ItemUrl, this property value does not include the URL scheme.
To parse an item path, use System.ItemUrl or System.ParsingPath. To reference shell namespace items using shell APIs, use System.ParsingPath.
Example values:
If the path is... The property value is... ----------------- ------------------------ "c:\foo\bar\hello.txt""c:\foo\bar\hello.txt" "\\server\share\mydir\goodnews.doc" "\\server\share\mydir\goodnews.doc" "\\server\share\numbers.xls" "\\server\share\numbers.xls" "c:\foo\MyFolder" "c:\foo\MyFolder" "/Mailbox Account/Inbox/'Re: Hello!'" "/Mailbox Account/Inbox/'Re: Hello!'"

Description: This is the user-friendly display path to the item. The format of the should be tailored such that the name comes first, to optimize for a narrow viewing column.
If the item is a file, the value excludes the file extension, and includes localized names if they are present. If the item is a message, the value includes the System.ItemNamePrefix.
To parse an item path, use System.ItemUrl or System.ParsingPath.
Example values:
If the path is... The property value is... ----------------- ------------------------ "c:\foo\bar\hello.txt""hello (c:\foo\bar)" "\\server\share\mydir\goodnews.doc" "goodnews (\\server\share\mydir)" "\\server\share\folder" "folder (\\server\share)" "c:\foo\MyFolder" "MyFolder (c:\foo)" "/Mailbox Account/Inbox/'Re: Hello!'" "Re: Hello! (/Mailbox Account/Inbox)"

Description: This is the canonical type of the item and is intended to be programmatically parsed.
If there is no canonical type, the value is .
If the item is a file (ie, System.FileName is not ), the value is the same as System.FileExtension.
Use System.ItemTypeText when you want to display the type to end users in a view. (If the item is a file, passing the System.ItemType value to PSFormatForDisplay will result in the same value as System.ItemTypeText.)
Example values:
If the path is... The property value is... ----------------- ------------------------ "c:\foo\bar\hello.txt"".txt" "\\server\share\mydir\goodnews.doc" ".doc" "\\server\share\folder" "Directory" "c:\foo\MyFolder" "Directory" [desktop] "Folder" "/Mailbox Account/Inbox/'Re: Hello!'" "MAPI/IPM.Message"

Description: This is the user friendly type name of the item. This is not intended to be programmatically parsed.
If System.ItemType is , the value of this property is also .
If the item is a file, the value of this property is the same as if you passed the file's System.ItemType value to PSFormatForDisplay.
This property should not be confused with System.Kind, where System.Kind is a high-level user friendly kind name. For example, for a document, System.Kind = "Document" and System.Item.Type = ".doc" and System.Item.TypeText = "Microsoft Word Document"
Example values:
If the path is... The property value is... ----------------- ------------------------ "c:\foo\bar\hello.txt""Text File" "\\server\share\mydir\goodnews.doc" "Microsoft Word Document" "\\server\share\folder" "File Folder" "c:\foo\MyFolder" "File Folder" "/Mailbox Account/Inbox/'Re: Hello!'" "Outlook E-Mail Message"

Description: This always represents a well formed URL that points to the item.
To reference shell namespace items using shell APIs, use System.ParsingPath.
Example values:
Files:"file:///c:/foo/bar/hello.txt" "csc://{GUID}/..." Messages: "mapi://..."
Description: The keywords for the item. Also referred to as tags.

summary.para: Description: Indicates the altitude based on the reference in PKEY_GPS_AltitudeRef. Calculated from PKEY_GPS_AltitudeNumerator and PKEY_GPS_AltitudeDenominator
Description: Indicates the reference for the altitude property. (eg: above sea level, below sea level, absolute value)
Description: Represents the name of the GPS area
Description: Date and time of the GPS record
Description: Indicates the bearing to the destination point. Calculated from PKEY_GPS_DestBearingNumerator and PKEY_GPS_DestBearingDenominator.
Description: Indicates the reference used for the giving the bearing to the destination point. (eg: true direction, magnetic direction)
Description: Indicates the distance to the destination point. Calculated from PKEY_GPS_DestDistanceNumerator and PKEY_GPS_DestDistanceDenominator.
Description: Indicates the unit used to express the distance to the destination. (eg: kilometers, miles, knots)

Description: Indicates the latitude of the destination point. This is an array of three values. Index 0 is the degrees, index 1 is the minutes, index 2 is the seconds. Each is calculated from the values in PKEY_GPS_DestLatitudeNumerator and PKEY_GPS_DestLatitudeDenominator.
Type: Multivalue Double -- | VT_R8 (For variants: | VT_R8)
Description: Indicates whether the latitude destination point is north or south latitude

Description: Indicates the latitude of the destination point. This is an array of three values. Index 0 is the degrees, index 1 is the minutes, index 2 is the seconds. Each is calculated from the values in PKEY_GPS_DestLongitudeNumerator and PKEY_GPS_DestLongitudeDenominator.
Type: Multivalue Double -- | VT_R8 (For variants: | VT_R8)
Description: Indicates whether the longitude destination point is east or west longitude
Description: Indicates whether differential correction was applied to the GPS receiver
Description: Indicates the GPS DOP (data degree of precision). Calculated from PKEY_GPS_DOPNumerator and PKEY_GPS_DOPDenominator
Description: Indicates direction of the image when it was captured. Calculated from PKEY_GPS_ImgDirectionNumerator and PKEY_GPS_ImgDirectionDenominator.

Description: Indicates the latitude. This is an array of three values. Index 0 is the degrees, index 1 is the minutes, index 2 is the seconds. Each is calculated from the values in PKEY_GPS_LatitudeNumerator and PKEY_GPS_LatitudeDenominator.
Type: Multivalue Double -- | VT_R8 (For variants: | VT_R8)
Description: Indicates whether latitude is north or south latitude

Description: Indicates the longitude. This is an array of three values. Index 0 is the degrees, index 1 is the minutes, index 2 is the seconds. Each is calculated from the values in PKEY_GPS_LongitudeNumerator and PKEY_GPS_LongitudeDenominator.
Type: Multivalue Double -- | VT_R8 (For variants: | VT_R8)
Description: Indicates whether longitude is east or west longitude
Description: Indicates the geodetic survey data used by the GPS receiver
Description: Indicates the GPS measurement mode. (eg: 2-dimensional, 3-dimensional)
Description: Indicates the name of the method used for location finding
Description: Indicates the GPS satellites used for measurements
Description: Indicates the speed of the GPS receiver movement. Calculated from PKEY_GPS_SpeedNumerator and PKEY_GPS_SpeedDenominator.
Description: Indicates the unit used to express the speed of the GPS receiver movement. (eg: kilometers per hour, miles per hour, knots).
Description: Indicates the status of the GPS receiver when the image was recorded. (eg: measurement in progress, measurement interoperability).
Description: Indicates the direction of the GPS receiver movement. Calculated from PKEY_GPS_TrackNumerator and PKEY_GPS_TrackDenominator.
Description: Indicates reference for the direction of the GPS receiver movement. (eg: true direction, magnetic direction)
Description: Indicates the version of the GPS information

summary.para: Description: The list of properties to show in the file operation conflict resolution dialog. Properties with empty values will not be displayed. Register under the regvalue of "ConflictPrompt".
Description: The list of properties to show in the content view mode of an item in the context of browsing. Register the regvalue under the name of "ContentViewModeForBrowse".
Description: The list of properties to show in the content view mode of an item in the context of searching. Register the regvalue under the name of "ContentViewModeForSearch".
Description: The list of properties to show in the listview on extended tiles. Register under the regvalue of "ExtendedTileInfo".

Description: The list of properties to show in the file operation confirmation dialog. Properties with empty values will not be displayed. If this list is not specified, then the InfoTip property list is used instead. Register under the regvalue of "FileOperationPrompt".

Description: The list of all the properties to show in the details page. Property groups can be included in this list in order to more easily organize the UI. Register under the regvalue of "FullDetails".
Description: The list of properties to show in the infotip. Properties with empty values will not be displayed. Register under the regvalue of "InfoTip".

Description: The list of properties that are considered 'non-personal'. When told to remove all non-personal properties from a given file, the system will leave these particular properties untouched. Register under the regvalue of "NonPersonal".
Description: The list of properties to display in the preview pane. Register under the regvalue of "PreviewDetails".
Description: The one or two properties to display in the preview pane title section. The optional second property is displayed as a subtitle. Register under the regvalue of "PreviewTitle".
Description: The list of properties to show in the infotip when the item is on a slow network. Properties with empty values will not be displayed. Register under the regvalue of "QuickTip".
Description: The list of properties to show in the listview on tiles. Register under the regvalue of "TileInfo".

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.PropertySystem.SystemProperties.System.Search
member.summary: Search Properties

summary.para: Description: General Summary of the document.
Description: Hash code used to identify attachments to be deleted based on a common container url
Description: The contents of the item. This property is for query restrictions only; it cannot be retrieved in a query result. The Indexing Service friendly name is 'contents'.
Description: The entry ID for an item within a given catalog in the Windows Search Index. This value may be recycled, and therefore is not considered unique over time.
Description: The that the Windows Search Gatherer process last pushed properties of this document to the Windows Search Gatherer Plugins.

Description: When using CONTAINS over the Windows Search Index, this is the number of matches of the term. If there are multiple CONTAINS, an AND computes the min number of hits and an OR the max number of hits.

Description: If this property is emitted with a value of TRUE, then it indicates that this URL's last modified time applies to all of it's children, and if this URL is deleted then all of it's children are deleted as well. For example, this would be emitted as TRUE when emitting the URL of an email so that all attachments are tied to the last modified time of that email.

Description: Any child URL of a URL which has System.Search.IsClosedDirectory=TRUE must emit System.Search.IsFullyContained=TRUE. This ensures that the URL is not deleted at the end of a crawl because it hasn't been visited (which is the normal mechanism for detecting deletes). For example an email attachment would emit this property
Description: Query Focused Summary of the document.
Description: Query Focused Summary of the document, if none is available it returns the AutoSummary.
Description: Relevance rank of row. Ranges from 0-1000. Larger numbers = better matches. Query-time only.
Description: The identifier for the protocol handler that produced this item. (E.g. MAPI, CSC, FILE etc.)
Description: This property should be emitted by a container IFilter for each child URL within the container. The children will eventually be crawled by the indexer if they are within scope.

Description: This property is the same as System.Search.UrlToIndex except that it includes the time the URL was last modified. This is an optimization for the indexer as it doesn't have to call back into the protocol handler to ask for this information to determine if the content needs to be indexed again. The property is a vector with two elements, a with the URL and a for the last modified time.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.IOperationsProgressDialog.StartProgressDialog(System.IntPtr,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.OPPROGDLG)
member.summary: Starts the specified progress dialog.
member.param: A handle to the parent window.
Flags that customize the operation. Note that these flags are declared in Shlobj.h.
member.returns: If this method succeeds, it returns . Otherwise, it returns an error code.

remarks.para: The progress dialog should be created on a separate thread than the file operation on which the dialog is reporting. If the dialog is running in the same thread as the file operation, progress messages are, at best, only sent as resources allow. Progress messages on the same thread as the file operation might not be sent at all.

Once is called, that instance of the CLSID_ProgressDialog object cannot be accessed by IProgressDialog, IActionProgressDialog, or IActionProgress. Although QueryInterface can be used to access these interfaces, most of their methods cannot be invoked. IOperationsProgressDialog is the interface used to display the new progress dialog for the Windows Vista and later operations engine.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.IFileOperationProgressSink.UpdateProgress(System.UInt32,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Provides an estimate of the total amount of work currently done in relation to the total amount of work.
member.param: An estimate of the amount of work to be completed.
The portion of iWorkTotal that has been completed so far.
member.returns: If this method succeeds, it returns . Otherwise, it returns an error code.
member.remarks: The iWorkTotal and iWorkSoFar values are "points" or estimates of the amount of work to be done, and how much is completed. They are not specified in any particular units, but should be roughly proportional to how much time the total process takes. For example, to copy one small file might be considered two points, and a large file might be considered ten points. If a process is performing an operation that copies five small files and one large file, and the process has completed four of the small files, iWorkSoFar would be eight points (4 x 2 = 8) and iWorkTotal would be twenty points (5 x 2 + 10 = 20), so the estimate would be 8 of 20 points (or 40%) complete.

member.summary: The value of the property and the value of the constant must be equal.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.SearchConditionOperation.NotEqual

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.SearchConditionOperation.LessThanOrEqual

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.SearchConditionOperation.ValueStartsWith

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.SearchConditionOperation.ValueContains

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.SearchConditionOperation.ValueNotContains

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.SearchConditionOperation.DosWildcards
member.summary: The value of the property must match the value of the constant, where '?' matches any single character and '*' matches any sequence of characters.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.SearchConditionOperation.WordEqual
member.summary: The value of the property must contain a word that is the value of the constant.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.SearchConditionOperation.WordStartsWith
member.summary: The value of the property must contain a word that begins with the value of the constant.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.SearchConditionOperation.ApplicationSpecific
member.summary: The application is free to interpret this in any suitable way.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.StructuredQuerySingleOption
member.summary: Provides a set of flags to be used with IQueryParser::SetOption and IQueryParser::GetOption to indicate individual options.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.StructuredQuerySingleOption.Schema
member.summary: The value should be VT_LPWSTR and the path to a file containing a schema binary.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.StructuredQuerySingleOption.Locale
member.summary: The value must be VT_EMPTY (the default) or a VT_UI4 that is an LCID. It is used as the locale of contents (not keywords) in the query to be searched for, when no other information is available. The default value is the current keyboard locale. Retrieving the value always returns a VT_UI4.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.StructuredQuerySingleOption.WordBreaker
member.summary: This option is used to override the default word breaker used when identifying keywords in queries. The default word breaker is chosen according to the language of the keywords (cf. SQSO_LANGUAGE_KEYWORDS below). When setting this option, the value should be VT_EMPTY for using the default word breaker, or a VT_UNKNOWN with an object supporting the IWordBreaker interface. Retrieving the option always returns a VT_UNKNOWN with an object supporting the IWordBreaker interface.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.StructuredQuerySingleOption.NaturalSyntax
member.summary: The value should be VT_EMPTY or VT_BOOL with VARIANT_TRUE to allow natural query syntax (the default) or VT_BOOL with VARIANT_FALSE to allow only advanced query syntax. Retrieving the option always returns a VT_BOOL. This option is now deprecated, use SQSO_SYNTAX.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.StructuredQuerySingleOption.AutomaticWildcard
member.summary: The value should be VT_BOOL with VARIANT_TRUE to generate query expressions as if each word in the query had a star appended to it (unless followed by punctuation other than a parenthesis), or VT_EMPTY or VT_BOOL with VARIANT_FALSE to use the words as they are (the default). A word-wheeling application will generally want to set this option to true. Retrieving the option always returns a VT_BOOL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.StructuredQuerySingleOption.TraceLevel
member.summary: Reserved. The value should be VT_EMPTY (the default) or VT_I4. Retrieving the option always returns a VT_I4.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.StructuredQuerySingleOption.LanguageKeywords
member.summary: The value must be a VT_UI4 that is a LANGID. It defaults to the default user UI language.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.StructuredQuerySingleOption.Syntax
member.summary: The value must be a VT_UI4 that is a STRUCTURED_QUERY_SYNTAX value. It defaults to SQS_NATURAL_QUERY_SYNTAX.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.StructuredQuerySingleOption.TimeZone
member.summary: The value must be a VT_BLOB that is a copy of a TIME_ZONE_INFORMATION structure. It defaults to the current time zone.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.StructuredQuerySingleOption.ImplicitConnector
member.summary: This setting decides what connector should be assumed between conditions when none is specified. The value must be a VT_UI4 that is a CONDITION_TYPE. Only CT_AND_CONDITION and CT_OR_CONDITION are valid. It defaults to CT_AND_CONDITION.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.StructuredQuerySingleOption.ConnectorCase
member.summary: This setting decides whether there are special requirements on the case of connector keywords (such as AND or OR). The value must be a VT_UI4 that is a CASE_REQUIREMENT value. It defaults to CASE_REQUIREMENT_UPPER_IF_AQS.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.StructuredQueryMultipleOption
member.summary: Provides a set of flags to be used with IQueryParser::SetMultiOption to indicate individual options.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.StructuredQueryMultipleOption.VirtualProperty
member.summary: The key should be property name P. The value should be a VT_UNKNOWN with an IEnumVARIANT which has two values: a VT_BSTR that is another property name Q and a VT_I4 that is a CONDITION_OPERATION cop. A predicate with property name P, some operation and a value V will then be replaced by a predicate with property name Q, operation cop and value V before further processing happens.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.StructuredQueryMultipleOption.DefaultProperty
member.summary: The key should be a value type name V. The value should be a VT_LPWSTR with a property name P. A predicate with no property name and a value of type V (or any subtype of V) will then use property P.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.StructuredQueryMultipleOption.GeneratorForType
member.summary: The key should be a value type name V. The value should be a VT_UNKNOWN with a IConditionGenerator G. The GenerateForLeaf method of G will then be applied to any predicate with value type V and if it returns a query expression, that will be used. If it returns NULL, normal processing will be used instead.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.StructuredQueryMultipleOption.MapProperty
member.summary: The key should be a property name P. The value should be a VT_VECTOR|VT_LPWSTR, where each string is a property name. The count must be at least one. This "map" will be added to those of the loaded schema and used during resolution. A second call with the same key will replace the current map. If the value is VT_NULL, the map will be removed.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.QueryParserManagerOption
member.summary: Used by IQueryParserManager::SetOption to set parsing options. This can be used to specify schemas and localization options.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.QueryParserManagerOption.SchemaBinaryName
member.summary: A VT_LPWSTR containing the name of the file that contains the schema binary. The default value is StructuredQuerySchema.bin for the SystemIndex catalog and StructuredQuerySchemaTrivial.bin for the trivial catalog.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.QueryParserManagerOption.PreLocalizedSchemaBinaryPath
member.summary: Either a VT_BOOL or a VT_LPWSTR. If the value is a VT_BOOL and is FALSE, a pre-localized schema will not be used. If the value is a VT_BOOL and is TRUE, IQueryParserManager will use the pre-localized schema binary in "%ALLUSERSPROFILE%\Microsoft\Windows". If the value is a VT_LPWSTR, the value should contain the full path of the folder in which the pre-localized schema binary can be found. The default value is VT_BOOL with TRUE.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.QueryParserManagerOption.UnlocalizedSchemaBinaryPath
member.summary: A VT_LPWSTR containing the full path to the folder that contains the unlocalized schema binary. The default value is "%SYSTEMROOT%\System32".

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.QueryParserManagerOption.LocalizedSchemaBinaryPath
member.summary: A VT_LPWSTR containing the full path to the folder that contains the localized schema binary that can be read and written to as needed. The default value is "%LOCALAPPDATA%\Microsoft\Windows".

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.QueryParserManagerOption.AppendLCIDToLocalizedPath
member.summary: A VT_BOOL. If TRUE, then the paths for pre-localized and localized binaries have "\(LCID)" appended to them, where language code identifier (LCID) is the decimal locale ID for the localized language. The default is TRUE.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.QueryParserManagerOption.LocalizerSupport
member.summary: A VT_UNKNOWN with an object supporting ISchemaLocalizerSupport. This object will be used instead of the default localizer support object.

summary.para: Prior to Windows Vista, operations could be undone only from the same process that performed the original operation.

In Windows Vista and later systems, the scope of the undo is a user session. Any process running in the user session can undo another operation. The undo state is held in the Explorer.exe process, and as long as that process is running, it can coordinate the undo functions.
If the source file parameter does not contain fully qualified path and file names, this flag is ignored.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellOperationFlags.FilesOnly
member.summary: Perform the operation only on files (not on folders) if a wildcard file name (.) is specified.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellOperationFlags.NoConfirmation
member.summary: Respond with Yes to All for any dialog box that is displayed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellOperationFlags.NoConfirmMkDir
member.summary: Do not confirm the creation of a new folder if the operation requires one to be created.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellOperationFlags.NoConnectedElements
member.summary: Do not move connected items as a group. Only move the specified files.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellOperationFlags.NoCopySecurityAttribs
member.summary: Do not copy the security attributes of the item.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellOperationFlags.NoErrorUI
member.summary: Do not display a message to the user if an error occurs. If this flag is set without , any error is treated as if the user had chosen Ignore or Continue in a dialog box. It halts the current action, sets a flag to indicate that an action was aborted, and proceeds with the rest of the operation.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellOperationFlags.NoRecursion
member.summary: Only operate in the local folder. Do not operate recursively into subdirectories.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellOperationFlags.RenameOnCollision
member.summary: Give the item being operated on a new name in a move, copy, or rename operation if an item with the target name already exists.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellOperationFlags.Silent
member.summary: Do not display a progress dialog box.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellOperationFlags.WantNukeWarning
member.summary: Send a warning if a file or folder is being destroyed during a delete operation rather than recycled. This flag partially overrides .

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellOperationFlags.AddUndoRecord
member.summary: Introduced in Windows 8. The file operation was user-invoked and should be placed on the undo stack. This flag is preferred to .

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellOperationFlags.NoSkipJunctions
member.summary: Walk into Shell namespace junctions. By default, junctions are not entered. For more information on junctions, see Specifying a Namespace Extension's Location.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellOperationFlags.PreferHardLink
member.summary: If possible, create a hard link rather than a new instance of the file in the destination.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellOperationFlags.ShowElevationPrompt
member.summary: If an operation requires elevated rights and the flag is set to disable error UI, display a UAC UI prompt nonetheless.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellOperationFlags.EarlyFailure
member.summary: If is set together with , the entire set of operations is stopped upon encountering any error in any operation. This flag is valid only when is set.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellOperationFlags.PreserveFileExtensions
member.summary: Rename collisions in such a way as to preserve file name extensions. This flag is valid only when is also set.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellOperationFlags.KeepNewerFile
member.summary: Keep the newer file or folder, based on the Date Modified property, if a collision occurs. This is done automatically with no prompt UI presented to the user.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellOperationFlags.NoCopyHooks
member.summary: Do not use copy hooks.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellOperationFlags.NoMinimizeBox
member.summary: Do not allow the progress dialog to be minimized.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellOperationFlags.MoveACLSAcrossVolumes
member.summary: Copy the security attributes of the source item to the destination item when performing a cross-volume move operation. Without this flag, the destination item receives the security attributes of its new folder.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellOperationFlags.DoNotDisplaySourcePath
member.summary: Do not display the path of the source item in the progress dialog.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellOperationFlags.DoNotDisplayDestPath
member.summary: Do not display the path of the destination item in the progress dialog.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellOperationFlags.RecycleOnDelete
member.summary: Introduced in Windows 8. When a file is deleted, send it to the Recycle Bin rather than permanently deleting it.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellOperationFlags.RequireElevation
member.summary: Introduced in Windows Vista SP1. The user expects a requirement for rights elevation, so do not display a dialog box asking for a confirmation of the elevation.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellOperationFlags.CopyAsDownload
member.summary: Introduced in Windows 7. Display a Downloading instead of Copying message in the progress dialog.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellOperationFlags.DoNotDisplayLocations
member.summary: Introduced in Windows 7. Do not display the location line in the progress dialog.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.PDMODE.Run
member.summary: The operation is running.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.PDMODE.Prelight

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.OPPROGDLG.Normal
member.summary: Default, normal progress dialog behavior.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.OPPROGDLG.Modal
member.summary: The dialog is modal to its hwndOwner. The default setting is modeless.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.OPPROGDLG.AutoTime
member.summary: Update "Line3" text with the time remaining. This flag does not need to be implicitly set because progress dialogs started by automatically display the time remaining.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.OPPROGDLG.NoTime
member.summary: Do not show the time remaining. We do not recommend setting this flag through because it goes against the purpose of the dialog.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.OPPROGDLG.NoMinimize

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.OPPROGDLG.NoProgressBar
member.summary: Do not display the progress bar.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.OPPROGDLG.MarqueeProgress
member.summary: This flag is invalid in this method. To set the progress bar to marquee mode, use the flags in .

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.OPPROGDLG.NoCancel

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.OPPROGDLG.Default

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.OPPROGDLG.EnablePause

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.OPPROGDLG.NoMultiDayEstimates

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.OPPROGDLG.DoNotDisplayLocations

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.AccessModes
member.summary:
The STGM constants are flags that indicate conditions for creating and deleting the object and access modes for the object.
You can combine these flags, but you can only choose one flag from each group of related flags. Typically one flag from each of the access and sharing groups must be specified for all functions and methods which use these constants.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.AccessModes.Direct
member.summary: Indicates that, in direct mode, each change to a storage or stream element is written as it occurs.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.AccessModes.Transacted
member.summary: Indicates that, in transacted mode, changes are buffered and written only if an explicit commit operation is called.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.AccessModes.Simple
member.summary: Provides a faster implementation of a compound file in a limited, but frequently used, case.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.AccessModes.Read
member.summary: Indicates that the object is read-only, meaning that modifications cannot be made.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.AccessModes.Write
member.summary: Enables you to save changes to the object, but does not permit access to its data.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.AccessModes.ReadWrite
member.summary: Enables access and modification of object data.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.AccessModes.SharedenyNone
member.summary: Specifies that subsequent openings of the object are not denied read or write access.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.AccessModes.SharedenyRead
member.summary: Prevents others from subsequently opening the object in Read mode.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.AccessModes.SharedenyWrite
member.summary: Prevents others from subsequently opening the object for Write or ReadWrite access.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.AccessModes.ShareExclusive
member.summary: Prevents others from subsequently opening the object in any mode.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.AccessModes.Priority
member.summary: Opens the storage object with exclusive access to the most recently committed version.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.AccessModes.DeleteOnRelease
member.summary: Indicates that the underlying file is to be automatically destroyed when the root storage object is released. This feature is most useful for creating temporary files.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.AccessModes.NoScratch
member.summary: Indicates that, in transacted mode, a temporary scratch file is usually used to save modifications until the Commit method is called. Specifying NoScratch permits the unused portion of the original file to be used as work space instead of creating a new file for that purpose.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.AccessModes.Create
member.summary: Indicates that an existing storage object or stream should be removed before the new object replaces it.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.AccessModes.Convert
member.summary: Creates the new object while preserving existing data in a stream named "Contents".

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.AccessModes.FailIfThere
member.summary: Causes the create operation to fail if an existing object with the specified name exists.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.AccessModes.NoSnapshot
member.summary: This flag is used when opening a storage object with Transacted and without ShareExclusive or .SharedenyWrite. In this case, specifying NoSnapshot prevents the system-provided implementation from creating a snapshot copy of the file. Instead, changes to the file are written to the end of the file.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.AccessModes.DirectSingleWriterMultipleReader
member.summary: Supports direct mode for single-writer, multireader file operations.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellThumbnailRetrievalOption
member.summary: Represents the different retrieval options for the thumbnail or icon, such as extracting the thumbnail or icon from a file, from the cache only, or from memory only.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellThumbnailRetrievalOption.Default
member.summary: The default behavior loads a thumbnail. If there is no thumbnail for the current ShellItem, the icon is retrieved. The thumbnail or icon is extracted if it is not currently cached.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellThumbnailRetrievalOption.CacheOnly
member.summary: The CacheOnly behavior returns a cached thumbnail if it is available. Allows access to the disk, but only to retrieve a cached item. If no cached thumbnail is available, a cached per-instance icon is returned but a thumbnail or icon is not extracted.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellThumbnailRetrievalOption.MemoryOnly
member.summary: The MemoryOnly behavior returns the item only if it is in memory. The disk is not accessed even if the item is cached. Note that this only returns an already-cached icon and can fall back to a per-class icon if an item has a per-instance icon that has not been cached yet. Retrieving a thumbnail, even if it is cached, always requires the disk to be accessed, so this method should not be called from the user interface (UI) thread without passing ShellThumbnailCacheOptions.MemoryOnly.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellThumbnailFormatOption
member.summary: Represents the format options for the thumbnails and icons.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellThumbnailFormatOption.Default
member.summary: The default behavior loads a thumbnail. An HBITMAP for the icon of the item is retrieved if there is no thumbnail for the current Shell Item.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellThumbnailFormatOption.ThumbnailOnly
member.summary: The ThumbnailOnly behavior returns only the thumbnails, never the icon. Note that not all items have thumbnails so ShellThumbnailFormatOption.ThumbnailOnly can fail in these cases.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.Shell.ShellThumbnailFormatOption.IconOnly
member.summary: The IconOnly behavior returns only the icon, never the thumbnail.

member.summary: A pointer to an array of values, each of which specifies a CLSID of a particular property page. This array is allocated by the callee using and is freed by the caller using .

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.COM.ISpecifyPropertyPages
member.summary: Indicates that an object supports property pages. OLE property pages enable an object to display its properties in a tabbed dialog box known as a property sheet. An end user can then view and change the object's properties. An object can display its property pages independent of its client, or the client can manage the display of property pages from a number of contained objects in a single property sheet. Property pages also provide a means for notifying a client of changes in an object's properties.

remarks.para: A property page object manages a particular page within a property sheet. A property page implements at least IPropertyPage and can optionally implement IPropertyPage2 if selection of a specific property is supported.

An object specifies its support for property pages by implementing . Through this interface the caller can obtain a list of CLSIDs identifying the specific property pages that the object supports. If the object specifies a property page CLSID, the object must be able to receive property changes from the property page.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.COM.ISpecifyPropertyPages.GetPages(Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.COM.CAUUID@)
member.summary: Retrieves a list of property pages that can be displayed in this object's property sheet.
member.remarks: A pointer to a caller-allocated structure that must be initialized and filled before returning. The pElems member in the structure is allocated by the callee with and freed by the caller with .

returns.para: This method can return the standard return values and , as well as the following values.

remarks.para: The structure is caller-allocated, but is not initialized by the caller. The method fills the cElements member in the structure. This method also allocates memory for the array pointed to by the pElems member using . Then, it fills the newly allocated array. After this method returns successfully, the structure contains a counted array of UUIDs, each UUID specifying a property page CLSID.
Notes to Callers: The caller must release the memory pointed to by the member of , using when it is no longer needed.
Notes to Implementers: is not allowed as a return value, because an object with no property pages should not expose the interface.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.MediaDevices.FormatCode
member.summary: The enumeration type defines a list of format codes that describe types of content transferred to and from a device.

remarks.para: To discover the formats supported by a device, an application can use to query the g_wszWMDMFormatsSupported device property.
To discover device capabilities for a particular format, an application can call .
An application can set the format code while creating a storage on device by including the g_wszWMDMFormatCode property in metadata passed in the pMetaData parameter of a call to .
An application can query the format code of a storage by calling or and retrieving the g_wszWMDMFormatCode property.

If the device supports setting the format code after the creation of storage, an application can use to set the g_wszWMDMFormatCode property. Some devices may not allow changing the format code after the storage is created on the device. Therefore, setting this property along with the metadata passed in is strongly recommended.

member.summary: Must be set to a format or formats supported by the device. Note that previous versions of the Windows Media Device Manager recommended using WMDM_WAVE_FORMAT_ALL to indicate support for all formats. However, this is no longer recommended, as different media players will interpret this in different ways, and few devices can truly play any file format. member.summary: The method retrieves the next one or more object IDs in the enumeration sequence.
member.param: A count of the objects requested.
An array of s, each specifying a retrieved object ID. The caller must allocate an array of elements. The caller must free both the array and the returned strings. The strings are freed by calling .
On input, this parameter is ignored. On output, the number of IDs actually retrieved. If no object IDs are released and the return value is , there are no more objects to enumerate.

returns.para: The method returns an . Possible values include, but are not limited to, those in the following list.

member.remarks: If fewer than the requested number of elements remain in the sequence, this method retrieves the remaining elements. The number of elements that are actually retrieved is returned through pcFetched (unless the caller passed in NULL for that parameter). Enumerated objects are all peers—that is, enumerating children of an object will enumerate only direct children, not grandchild or deeper objects.

member.summary: The method cancels a pending operation.

returns.para: The method returns an . Possible values include, but are not limited to, those in the following list.

summary.para: The interface provides access to a portable device.
To create and open this interface, first call with or to retrieve an interface, and then call to open a connection to the device.

remarks.para: The client interfaces are designed to be used for any WPD object; it is not necessary to create a new instance for each object referenced by the application. After an application opens an instance of the interface, it should open and cache any other WPD client interfaces that it will require.

For Windows 7, supports two CLSIDs for . returns an pointer that does not aggregate the free-threaded marshaler; is a new CLSID that returns an pointer that aggregates the free-threaded marshaler.Both pointers support the same functionality otherwise.
Applications that live in Single Threaded Apartments should use as this eliminates the overhead of interface pointer marshaling. is still supported for legacy applications.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.IPortableDevice.Open(System.String,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.PropertySystem.IPortableDeviceValues)
member.summary: The method opens a connection between the application and the device.
member.param: A reference to a null-terminated string that contains the Plug and Play ID string for the device. You can get this string by calling .

param.name: pClientInfo
param.para: A reference to an interface that holds information that identifies the application to the device. This interface holds PROPERTYKEY/value pairs that try to identify an application uniquely. Although the presence of a CoCreated interface is required, the application is not required to send any key/value pairs. However, sending data might improve performance. Typical key/value pairs include the application name, major and minor version, and build number.
See properties beginning with "WPD_CLIENT_" in the Properties section.

returns.para: The method returns an . Possible values include, but are not limited to, those in the following list.

remarks.para: A device must be opened before you can call any methods on it. (Note that the methods do not require you to open a device before calling any methods.) However, usually you do not need to call .

Administrators can restrict the access of portable devices to computers running on a network.For example, an administrator may restrict all Guest users to read-only access, while Authenticated users are given read/write access.

Due to these security issues, if your application will not perform write operations, it should call the method and request read-only access by specifying GENERIC_READ for the WPD_CLIENT_DESIRED_ACCESS property that it supplies in the pClientInfo parameter.

If your application requires write operations, it should call the method as shown in the following example code. The first time, it should request read/write access by passing the default WPD_CLIENT_DESIRED_ACCESS property in the pClientInfo parameter.If this first call fails and returns E_ACCESSDENIED, your application should call the method a second time and request read-only access by specifying GENERIC_READ for the WPD_CLIENT_DESIRED_ACCESS property that it supplies in the pClientInfo parameter.
Applications that live in Single Threaded Apartments should use , as this eliminates the overhead of interface pointer marshaling. is still supported for legacy applications.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.IPortableDevice.SendCommand(System.UInt32,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.PropertySystem.IPortableDeviceValues@,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.PropertySystem.IPortableDeviceValues@)
member.summary: The method sends a command to the device and retrieves the results synchronously.
member.param: Currently not used; specify zero.

param.name: pParameters
param.para: Reference to an interface that specifies the command and parameters to call on the device. This interface must include the following two values to indicate the command. Additional parameters vary depending on the command. For a list of the parameters that are required for each command, see Commands.

member.param: Address of a variable that receives a pointer to an interface that indicates the results of the command results, including success or failure, and any command values returned by the device. The caller must release this interface when it is done with it. The retrieved values vary by command; see the appropriate command documentation in Commands to learn what values are returned by each command call.

returns.para: The returned value indicates success or failure to send a command and return a result from the driver; it does not indicate whether the driver supports the command or if it encountered some error in processing the command. (For more information, see Remarks.) These errors are returned in the values of the parameter. The possible values returned by this method include, but are not limited to, those in the following list.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.IPortableDevice.Cancel
member.summary: The method cancels a pending operation on this interface.

returns.para: The method returns an . Possible values include, but are not limited to, those in the following list.

remarks.para: If your application invokes the WPD API from multiple threads, each thread should create a new instance of the interface. Doing this ensures that any cancel operation affects only the I/O for the affected thread.

If an write operation is underway when the method is invoked, your application should discard all changes by invoking the method. Once the changes are discarded, the application should also close the stream by invoking the IUnknown.Release method.
Also, note that if the method is invoked before an method has completed, the data being written may be corrupted.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.IPortableDevice.Close
member.summary: The method closes the connection with the device.

returns.para: The method returns an . Possible values include, but are not limited to, those in the following list.

member.remarks: You should not usually need to call this method yourself. When the last reference to the interface is released, Windows Portable Devices calls for you. Calling this method manually forces the connection to the device to close, and any Windows Portable Devices objects hosted on this device will cease to function. You can call to reopen the connection.

member.summary: The method retrieves a list of all the supported commands for this device.
member.param: Reference to an interface that holds all the valid commands. For a list of commands that are defined by Windows Portable Devices, see Commands. The caller must release this interface when it is done with it.

returns.para: The method returns an . Possible values include, but are not limited to, those in the following list.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.IPortableDeviceCapabilities.GetCommandOptions(Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.PropertySystem.PropertyKey@,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.PropertySystem.IPortableDeviceValues@)
member.summary: The method retrieves all the supported options for the specified command on the device.
member.param: A that specifies a command to query for supported options. For a list of the commands that are defined by Windows Portable Devices, see Commands.

Address of a variable that receives a pointer to an interface that contains the supported options. If no options are supported, this will not contain any values. The caller must release this interface when it is done with it. For more information, see Remarks.

returns.para: The method returns an HResult. Possible values include, but are not limited to, those in the following list.

remarks.para: This method is called by applications that want to call a command directly on the driver by calling . Some commands allow the caller to specify additional options. For example, some drivers support recursive child deletion when deleting an object using the WPD_COMMAND_OBJECT_MANAGEMENT_DELETE_OBJECTS command.

If an option is a simple value, the key of the retrieved interface will be the name of the option, and the value will be a value of or . If an option has several values, the retrieved value will be a collection type that holds the supported values.

If this method is called for the WPD_COMMAND_STORAGE_FORMAT command and the ppOptions parameter is set to WPD_OPTION_VALID_OBJECT_IDS, the driver will return an IPortableDevicePropVariant collection of type that specifies the identifiers for each object on the device that can be formatted. (If this option does not exist, the format command is available for all objects.)

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.IPortableDeviceCapabilities.GetFunctionalCategories(Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.PropertySystem.IPortableDevicePropVariantCollection@)
member.summary: The method retrieves all functional categories supported by the device.
member.param: Reference to an interface that holds all the functional categories for this device. The values will be s of type VT_CLSID in the retrieved values. The caller must release this interface when it is done with it.

returns.para: The method returns an HResult. Possible values include, but are not limited to, those in the following list.

remarks.para: Functional categories describe the types of functions that a device can perform, such as image capture, audio capture, and storage. This method is typically very fast, because the driver usually queries the device only on startup and caches the results.
For an example of how to use this method see Retrieving the Functional Categories Supported by a Device.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.IPortableDeviceCapabilities.GetFunctionalObjects(System.Guid@,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.PropertySystem.IPortableDevicePropVariantCollection@)
member.summary: The method retrieves all functional objects that match a specified category on the device.
member.param: A reference to a that specifies the category to search for. This can be WPD_FUNCTIONAL_CATEGORY_ALL to return all functional objects.

A reference to an interface that contains the object IDs of the functional objects as strings (type in the retrieved items). If no objects of the requested type are found, this will be an empty collection (not ). The caller must release this interface when it is done with it.

returns.para: The method returns an HResult. Possible values include, but are not limited to, those in the following list.

remarks.para: This operation is usually fast, because the driver does not need to perform a full content enumeration, and the number of retrieved functional objects is typically less than 10. If no objects of the requested type are found, this method will not return an error, but returns an empty collection for .
For an example of how to use this method, see Retrieving the Functional Object Identifiers for a Device

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.IPortableDeviceCapabilities.GetSupportedContentTypes(System.Guid@,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.PropertySystem.IPortableDevicePropVariantCollection@)
member.summary: The method retrieves all supported content types for a specified functional object type on a device.
member.param: A reference to a that specifies a functional object category. To get a list of functional categories on the device, call .

Reference to an interface that lists all the supported object types for the specified functional object category. These object types will be values of type VT_CLSID in the retrieved items. See Requirements for Objects for a list of object types defined by Windows Portable Devices. The caller must release this interface when it is done with it.

returns.para: The method returns an HResult. Possible values include, but are not limited to, those in the following list.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.IPortableDeviceCapabilities.GetFixedPropertyAttributes(System.Guid@,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.PropertySystem.PropertyKey@,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.PropertySystem.IPortableDeviceValues@)
member.summary: The method retrieves the standard property attributes for a specified property and format. Standard attributes are those that have the same value for all objects of the same format. For example, one device might not allow users to modify video file names; this device would return WPD_PROPERTY_ATTRIBUTE_CAN_WRITE with a value of False for WMV formatted objects. Attributes that can have different values for a format, or optional attributes, are not returned.
member.param: A reference to a that specifies the format of the objects of interest. For format values, see Object Formats.
A reference to a that specifies the property that you want to know the attributes of. Properties defined by Windows Portable Devices are listed in Properties and Attributes.
Reference to an interface that holds the attributes and their values. The caller must release this interface when it is done with it.

returns.para: The method returns an HResult. Possible values include, but are not limited to, those in the following list.

remarks.para: You can specify WPD_OBJECT_FORMAT_ALL for the Format parameter to retrieve the complete set of property attributes.
Attributes describe properties. Example attributes are WPD_PROPERTY_ATTRIBUTE_CAN_READ and WPD_PROPERTY_ATTRIBUTE_CAN_WRITE. This method does not retrieve resource attributes.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.IPortableDeviceCapabilities.Cancel
member.summary: The method cancels a pending request on this interface.

returns.para: The method returns an HResult. Possible values include, but are not limited to, those in the following list.

member.remarks: This method cancels all pending operations on the current device handle, which corresponds to a session associated with an interface. The Windows Portable Devices (WPD) API does not support targeted cancellation of specific operations.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.IPortableDeviceCapabilities.GetEventOptions(System.Guid@,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.PropertySystem.IPortableDeviceValues@)
member.summary: The method retrieves all the supported options for the specified event on the device.
member.param: A reference to a that specifies a event to query for supported options. For a list of the events that are defined by Windows Portable Devices, see Events.

Address of a variable that receives a pointer to an interface that contains the supported options. If no options are supported, this will not contain any values. The caller must release this interface when it is done with it.

returns.para: The method returns an HResult. Possible values include, but are not limited to, those in the following list.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.PropertySystem.DeviceTypeValues
member.summary: This enum describes the different Windows Portable Device (WPD) types commonly used to determine the basic classification and visual appearance of a portable device.

remarks.para: are read using the interface. WPD applications may use these values to determine the generic visual appearance of the device. That is, a camera picture is displayed for camera-like devices, a mobile phone picture is displayed for phone-like devices, and so on.
Note: WPD applications must use the capabilities of the portable device to determine functionally, not the value.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.PropertySystem.DeviceTypeValues.Generic
member.summary: A generic WPD that includes multifunction devices that do not fall into one of the other enumeration values.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.PropertySystem.DeviceTypeValues.Camera
member.summary: A camera device, such as a digital still camera.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.PropertySystem.DeviceTypeValues.MediaPlayer
member.summary: A media player device that supports playing audio, video, or viewing pictures, such as a portable music player or portable media center. Not all of this functionally is classified as a WPD_DEVICE_TYPE_MEDIA_PLAYER. For example, portable music player devices are classified as WPD_DEVICE_TYPE_MEDIA_PLAYER.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.PropertySystem.DeviceTypeValues.Phone
member.summary: A phone device, such as a mobile phone.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.PropertySystem.DeviceTypeValues.Video
member.summary: A video device.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.PropertySystem.DeviceTypeValues.PersonalInformationManager
member.summary: A personal information manager device.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.COMNative.PortableDevices.PropertySystem.DeviceTypeValues.AudioRecorder
member.summary: An audio recorder device.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.PortableDevices.PropertySystem.Properties.Object
member.summary: This class defines all Commands-Parameters and Options associated with: and . This category is for all common object properties.

summary.para: Description: The abstract type for the object content-indicating the kinds of properties and data that may be supported on the object.
Description: of type VT_LPWSTR indicating a list of ObjectIDs.

Description: Indicates the Object ID of the closest functional object ancestor. For example-objects that represent files/folders under a Storage functional object-will have this property set to the object ID of the storage functional object.
Description: Indicates whether the thumbnail for this object should be generated from the default resource.
Description: If this object appears as a hint location-this property indicates the hint-specific name to display instead of the object name.
Description: Indicates the units supported on this object.
Description: Indicates the object's functional category.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.PortableDevices.PropertySystem.Properties.Storage
member.summary: This class defines all Commands-Parameters and Options associated with: . This category is for properties common to all objects whose functional category is .

summary.para: Description: Indicates the type of storage e.g. fixed-removable etc.
Description: Indicates the file system type e.g. "FAT32" or "NTFS" or "My Special File System"
Description: Indicates the total storage capacity in bytes.
Description: Indicates the available space in bytes.
Description: Indicates the available space in objects e.g. available slots on a SIM card.
Description: Contains a description of the storage.
Description: Contains the serial number of the storage.
Description: Specifies the maximum size of a single object (in bytes) that can be placed on this storage.
Description: Indicates the total storage capacity in objects e.g. available slots on a SIM card.
Description: This property identifies any write-protection that globally affects this storage. This takes precedence over access specified on individual objects.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.PortableDevices.PropertySystem.Properties.StillImageCapture
member.summary: This class defines all Commands-Parameters and Options associated with: . This category is for properties common to all objects whose functional category is WPD_FUNCTIONAL_CATEGORY_STILL_IMAGE_CAPTURE

summary.para: Description: Controls the size of the image dimensions to capture in pixel width and height.
Description: Controls the format of the image to capture.
Description: Controls the device-specific quality setting.
Description: Controls how the device weights color channels.
Description: Controls the aperture of the lens.
Description: Controls the 35mm equivalent focal length.
Description: This property corresponds to the focus distance in millimeters
Description: Identifies the focusing mode used by the device for image capture.
Description: Identifies the exposure metering mode used by the device for image capture.
Description: Controls the shutter speed of the device.
Description: Controls the exposure program mode of the device.
Description: Controls the emulation of film speed settings.
Description: Controls the adjustment of the auto exposure control.
Description: Controls the amount of time delay between the capture trigger and the actual data capture (in milliseconds).
Description: Controls the type of still image capture.
Description: Controls the perceived contrast of captured images.
Description: Controls the perceived sharpness of the captured image.
Description: Controls the effective zoom ratio of a digital camera's acquired image scaled by a factor of 10.
